messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] what theme is this?
messages.msgSnippet: I ve added an example with a similar motif from one of the Haynes catalogues as a comparison: http://zincavage.org/BannersTsuba.html ... From: Richard George
messages.messageBody:
I've added an example with a similar motif from one of the Haynes catalogues as a comparison:

http://zincavage.org/BannersTsuba.html


----- Original Message -----
From: Richard George
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, November 27, 2005 10:29 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] what theme is this?


Hey guys,

Can anybody tell me what the meaning of the theme on this tsuba is?

http://home.teleport.com/~rkg/photos/tsuba/tosho3_front_small.JPG

I'm thinking about getting it mounted for iai, and...

thanks,

rkg
(Richard George)

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] what theme is this?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Richard, Sasano has a similar on that is part of a 4 way Family crest theme. He calls them Parallel Crossbars ( /fatatsu-hikiryo/ ) Cheers Richard Turner
messages.messageBody:
Hi Richard, Sasano has a similar on that is part of a 4 way Family crest
theme. He calls them Parallel Crossbars ( /fatatsu-hikiryo/ )

Cheers

Richard Turner

messages.subject: Re: what theme is this?
messages.msgSnippet: Eckhard Kremers show this crossed bar design in his Sukashi Tsuba , pg. 44, as being Jogi -- ruler or angular measure.  There is also a mon which uses
messages.messageBody:
Eckhard Kremers show this crossed bar design in his 'Sukashi Tsuba',
pg. 44, as being Jogi -- ruler or angular measure. There is also a mon
which uses parallel bars as rolls of silk. Fun!
Pete Klein

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] what theme is this?
messages.msgSnippet: Battle banners or poetry scrolls.  The former is more commonly attributed to this kind of design. ... From: Richard George To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
messages.messageBody:
Battle banners or poetry scrolls. The former is more commonly attributed to this kind of design.
